Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Social Norms, Trust, and Intergenerational Flow of Innovations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Increased productivity and economic growth partly depends on adoption of improved technology which in turn depends on the transmission of information about new technologies. Young people tend to learn about new technologies before their parents who own productive resources and are wedded to old technologies and may not trust the new information they learn from the young. On the other hand, young people may mistrust elders and may not reveal appropriate information they think elders will not accept, thus slowing technical progress and economic growth. This research project will use theory and experiments to study how social norms affect the intergenerational flow of technological information and how best to solve this friction in information flow. In addition to intergenerational transmission of information, the research also studies whether there is a gender dimension to the intergenerational flow of technological information. The results of this study could influence the design of effective information interventions that induce intergenerational flows of knowledge to speed up technical progress. The results will offer valuable information on the constraints in the economic empowerment of young women. The results of this research has the potential to increase the pace of innovation and accelerate economic growth, and improve the living standards of Americans. <br/> <br/>This research project will leverage a collaboration with NGO partners in 150 junior high schools to study the barriers in intergenerational flow of knowledge. The project focuses on beliefs held by parents regarding the level and relevance of students’ school-taught technical knowledge, as well as students’ assessments of parents’ beliefs. It examines whether parents and students hold systematically biased beliefs; relates these biases to conventional roles prescribed for different configurations of parents and students by gender; and measures the effects of beliefs on intergenerational communication patterns, parents’ acquisition of new technical knowledge, and the empowerment of youth. The research proceeds in four stages. First, a baseline survey will collect household demographics of participants in a school-based technical education program. Second, the PIs will elicit parents’ and students’ beliefs in interviews; and deliver technical information to a random subset of parents and students. Third, the PIs will survey productive inputs allocated to youth for their home production, the acquisition of new technical knowledge among parents as well as communication patterns between students and parents. Finally, the study will track the impact of the information interventions on production patterns after two school years. The results of this research has the potential to increase the pace of innovation and accelerate economic growth, thus improving the living standards of Americans.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In an effort to advance food security, alleviate poverty, and establish a system in which innovative rural communities in Liberia adopt agricultural technologies, we implemented school-based agricultural education (SBAE) programs in 100 Liberian junior and senior high schools in four counties. This project specifically focused on the training of agriculture teachers at these schools. From 2020 to 2021, we designed and offered over one dozen multi-day trainings to agriculture teachers and Ministry of Agriculture Field Officers to implement SBAE on several topics. These topics included workshops on the purposes and benefits of SBAE, how to start a 4-H club, relevant agricultural innovations such as farming practices that increase soil fertility, student-centered teaching methods, how to establish a school demonstration farm, and how to work with students to create home entrepreneurship projects.

In total, 395 individuals attended over one dozen multi-day trainings. Participants included 182 teachers, 57 members of various parent-teacher associations, and 117 school principals. We utilized pre- and post-training surveys to measure participant learning, reactions to the trainings, intentions to adopt training material, and changes participants anticipate because of implementation. Overall, the results were positive and indicated the participants not only learned the content presented in the training but were enthusiastic about taking what they learned and bringing it back to their school and community. The pre-and post-knowledge tests showed statistically significant increases in knowledge from each teacher training with large effect sizes. Also, participants, on average, expressed that they intended to use the information about the overall School-Based agricultural education model, the 4 H model, student-centered pedagogical practices, how to start a school demonstration farm, and the innovative practices they learned during the training. Additionally, participants were hopeful that implementing SBAE in their schools would result in positive outcomes for their students, communities, and countries. For example, they expect students to bring the agricultural innovations learned in their SBAE program back home to farming parents who will, in turn, see the benefits of said innovations and adopt them into their own practices, thus resulting in higher yields and better quality of life. While this project was just the beginning of a long-term study investigating the economic outcomes of SBAE programs, we are excited to see the passion expressed by the Liberian agriculture teachers to implement SBAE programs in their schools and make a positive difference in the lives of their communities.
